references:
In our optimization, we have three weight parameters w1subscript𝑤1w_{1}, w2subscript𝑤2w_{2}, and ρ𝜌\rho, where w1+w2=1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤21w_{1}+w_{2}=1 as explained above. If w1>w2subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2w_{1}>w_{2}, energy consumption will take a more dominant position in our optimization problem. If w2>w1subscript𝑤2subscript𝑤1w_{2}>w_{1}, it is more important to optimize the delay instead of energy.
Analogously, if the weight parameter ρ𝜌\rho is larger, the model accuracy will take a more dominant position. To explore the effect of weight parameters of total energy and time consumption and model accuracy separately, we first show experiments under different (w1,w2)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2(w_{1},w_{2}) with fixed ρ𝜌\rho and then show results under different ρ𝜌\rho with fixed (w1,w2)=(0.5,0.5)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤20.50.5(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.5,0.5). The algorithms to be compared with are summarized in Table I (comparison with other work is in Section VII-D).

references:
In this paper, we formulate a joint optimization of energy, completion time and model accuracy problem in FL via Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA). FDMA means the spectral resources are divided among MAR devices. Each device is assigned a unique frequency band, which is dedicated to that user for the communication duration. The objective function is a weighted combination of total energy, time, and model accuracy. Total energy consumption, total completion time and model accuracy model are discussed in Sections III-A, III-B and III-C, respectively.
Notations in this paper are listed in Table II in Appendix A. Bold symbols stand for vectors.
